Oehlers a, R. Fehrmann b,,, S.G. Masters b, K.M. Eriksen b, D.E. Sheinin c B.S. Bal'zhinimaev c V.I. Elokhin c a BP Chemicals Limited, Research Laboratory, Poplar House, Chertsev Road Sunbuty-on-Thames, Middlesex TW16 7LN, UK h Department of Chemistry, Building 207, Technical Universi~ of Denmark, DK-2800 Lyngby, Denmark c Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Noc'osibirsk 630090, Russia Received 26 February 1996; revised 31 May 1996; accepted 31 May 1996 Abstract Deactivation processes of commercial and prototype sulphuric acid catalysts have been investigated in-situ both in highly converted and unconverted feed gases, using electron paramag- netic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. The investigation revealed that the deactivation of catalysts for SO2 oxidation is strongly dependent on physical and chemical parameters such as the pore structure of the support, the type of the alkali promoter as well as the SO2 and SO3 partial pressures. A hysteresis effect in catalytic activity could be observed during reheating of the deactivated catalysts. In this context indirect evidence was found of deactivation by the formation of vanadium(III) compounds. The various vanadium compounds in the oxidation state (IV) and with mixed valence (IV-V), formed during deactivation, have been characterized by EPR. The investigations showed no change in the vanadium oxidation state in the catalytic cycle under steady-state conditions, and at high SO2 partial pressure even at low temperatures, indicating that the so-called 'associative mechanism' probably dominates in the catalytic SO2 oxidation. A statistical lattice model was applied to describe the crystallization of binuclear complexes in the melt of snlphuric acid catalysts during deactivation while taking into account parameters such as temperature, the composition of the catalyst and SO2 conversion. Keywords." SO2 oxidation: Deactivation; Activity; Crystallization modelling; EPR; UV-spectrophotometry 1. Introduction Sulphuric acid is the chemical made in the largest volumes in both Europe and in the United States. The oxidation reaction SO2 + 1/202 ~ SO3 cat- * Corresponding author. Fax: (+45) 45883136. 0926-860X/96/$15.00 Copyright 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(96)00200- 1 128 C. Oehlers et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 147 (1996) 127-144 alyzed by the alkali-promoted vanadium catalysts is the key process which has recently also been applied for emission control, for example, in sulphuric acid production by desulphurization of flue gases. Numerous kinetic investigations regarding the oxidation of SO2 with pro- moted vanadium catalysts under steady state [1-4] and non-steady state condi- tions [5-7] have been reported, but a kinetic model, describing the catalytic process in a wide range of temperatures and pressures, is still not available; this is because of the complex processes which take place in the melt, are located in the catalyst pores. Therefore the characterization of deactivation compounds, the role of active vanadium species and a model describing crystallization processes in the catalyst pores, as depicted in the present paper, could be an important step forward to understand the essential reactions in the catalytic cycle of SO2 oxidation. The present study also shows the significant influence on the deacti- vation process of sulphuric acid catalysts by chemical and physical parameters such as the type of the alkali promoter, the gas composition and the pore size of the support. The investigated catalysts consisted of 6-9% V205, 6-12% K20, Na20 and/or Cs20 on an inert carrier. The alkali oxides, which are promoters for the catalyst, take up SO3 during catalytic operation and form a mixture of sulphates and pyrosulphates that act as the solvent for the catalytically active species [8,9]. This type of catalyst is referred to as a 'supported liquid phase' (SLP)-catalyst and its activity depends on various chemical and physical properties [10-13]. The experimental investigations were conducted applying electron paramag- netic resonance (EPR) in combination with UV- spe~trophotometry and gaschro- matography for monitoring the amount of paramag~etic vanadium(IV) [Ar] 3d~ compounds formed, as well as the SO2 and SO3 .partial pressures. Thus, the vanadium(IV) complex formation and the catalytictactivity could be measured simultaneously in situ. During catalysis, vanadium(V) is partly reduced to the lower oxidation states (IV) and (III) which play an important role in the deactivation process of the catalysts [3,11-17] taking place around 420. The EPR spectra of the commercial Russian catalyst IK-1-6 and six prototype catalysts were compared with spectra of compounds isolated from the molten salt/gas system M2S207-V2Os/SO2-O2-SO3-N2 (M = Na, K or Cs), which is considered a realistic model for the catalyst used for sulphuric acid production [4]. 2. The EPR spectrometer was a modified JEOL JES-ME-1X instrument equipped with a high temperature cavity (Bruker ER4114HT) operating up to 1000. The C. The catalyst pellets were gently crushed and about 30 mg were placed in the inner tube of the cell between two plugs of quartz wool. The temperature was measured by a non-magnetic chromel-constantan thermocou- ple in contact with the catalyst. The probe was positioned between the pole caps of a 6 inch magnet with a variable field range of 500-6500 Gauss. The gas composition before and after the reactor cell was monitored by a UV/VIS/NIR spectrometer (Perkin Elmer Lambda 9) and by a GC (Shimadzu GC-8APT) with a 4-m stainless steel column containing Supelco Chromosorp 102 or a molecular sieve 5A, after absorption of SO3 in 96% H2SO4. Helium served as carrier gas. The feed gas was premixed in special gas steel bottles using dry sulphur dioxide, oxygen and nitrogen of commercial purities. The on-line gas mixing unit used in the present work consisted of Brooks mass flow controllers (Model 5810) with a flow range from 0 to 1000 cm3/min. The gas stream was dried through a phosphorous pentoxide (Sicapent, Merck) column and then led to the preconverter or directly into the reactor cell. The preconverter consisted of a 2 cm i.d. quartz glass tube which was filled with platinated silica [12]. The preconverter was operated at 520 to 580 to obtain 80 to 90% conversion with a flow rate of 10 cm3/min. The conversion in the reactor cell of any gas mixture was below 20% and the reactor could therefore be considered differen- tial. Further details of the experimental set-up and the reactor cell applied for the synthesis of VTM and Vv compounds from the molten salt gas system M2S207- V2Os/SO2-O2-SO3-N2 can be found elsewhere [12,13]. The catalyst samples were manufactured by the Boreskov Institut of Catalysis, Novosibirsk, Russia. 3. A 'hysteresis effect' could be observed when the catalysts were reheated in order to regain their full activity. This catalytic hysteresis was investigated for the catalysts IK-739 and IK-768 with nearly the same catalyst specifications but a different porous structure of the support and is depicted in Fig. 5. As seen in Fig. 5a for both catalysts, by reheating, the relative vanadium(IV) concentration drops below the curve obtained by lowering of the temperature, probably due to precipitation of minor amounts of EPR silent vanadium(III) compounds. The catalytic activity is regained after reheating at approximately 480 as shown in Fig. 5b. In order to further investigate the influence of the pore structure on the deactivation process, one sample of the powderous IK-739 catalyst was pel- letized under pressure (p = 0.3 GPa). A different hysteresis behavior could be observed compared with the nonpressed sample of the IK-739, as shown in Fig. 5b. Furthermore, a different vanadium(IV) deactivation compound was formed, judged from the EPR spectra (not shown). 4. Discussion 4.1. Catalyst activity and deactivation The EPR investigations revealed that the deactivation temperature of the catalysts is dependent on the type of the alkali promoter. The catalysts contain- ing cesium show an enhanced activity at lower temperatures compared with catalysts based on potassium and sodium promoters. The increasing radius of the alkali metal ions in the sequence Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs leads to a stabilisation of active vanadium compounds in the oxidation state (V) by stabilising pyrosul- phates and higher pyrosulphates [19-21]. The amount of pyrosulphate ions is sufficient for the formation of active complexes even for the lighter alkalimetal ions due to the high solubility of SO3. Simonova et al. [22] showed, by quantitative analysis of EPR spectra, that the content of crystalline vanadium(IV) does not exceed 50% of the total vanadium amount at 420 and 30% SO2 conversion for cesium catalysts with a molar ratio M/V = 2. On the other hand their investigations revealed, under the same reaction conditions, that in the catalysts containing sodium and potassium all vanadium is found as inactive crystalline compounds. The results are in accordance with our measurements of sulphufic acid catalysts and model systems, here and previously [ 12,13]. The deactivation process, in particular the increase of vanadium(III) and (IV) deactivation compounds in the pores of the SLP-catalyst as well as the sudden drop of activity in the Arrhenius plots, is dependent on the SO3/SO2 partial pressure ratio. It turned out that the deactivation temperature of the investigated catalysts is approximately 20-30 lower in the 85% preconverted gas com- C. Oehlers et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 147 (1996) 127-144 137 pared with the unconverted feed gas. This is probably due to a shift of the formal equilibrium system SO2 .. SO2 .,. vV~v'*~V" (1) SO3 SO3 to the left, since the partial pressure ratio p(SO3)/p(SO2) is larger compared to the unconverted feed gas, as proposed recently [13]. Thus, the solubility limit of vanadium species in the oxidation states (lid and (IV) is achieved at lower temperature in the 85% preconverted gas and Tb is accordingly lower. This phenomenon is confirmed by recent spectrophotometric and EPR measurements on dilute solutions of vanadium pentoxide in molten pyrosulphates [23]. From a technical point of view these results are important for the cost-effective design of a new type of industrial converter without interstage absorption of SO3. In this context the catalysts IK-739, IK-768 and IK-741 show promising results at low and high SO3 partial pressures, although the desired deactivation tempera- ture Tb ~< 350 is not reached, yet. Physical parameters as the pore geometry and size of the catalyst support have an effect on the liquid distribution and the deactivation process. The deactivation temperature of the catalyst IK-741 with a special porous structure is approximately 20 lower in comparison with the catalyst IK-752. The tempera- ture deviation between the catalysts IK-739 and IK-768 is approximately 10, and no effect can be noticed for the catalysts IK-748 and IK-821 as presented in Table 2. Belyaeva et al. [24] investigated the activity of a potassium promoted vanadium catalyst in dependency of the silica gel pore size structure. They also found that at low conversion the on-set of crystallization of the active com- pounds is shifted to lower temperatures for catalysts with small pore sizes, i.e. between 10 and 80 nm. Their explanation for this phenomenon is based on the Gibbs-Thomson equation Gq = c,~ exp(2 6 Vo/rkT) (2) This states, that the equilibrium concentration Ceq of the precipitating vana- dium(IV) increases by decreasing radius r of the crystals, ca is the equilibrium concentration of the precipitating species in a solution with infinitely large crystals, i.e. coo is the solubility, ~ is the free surface energy, V0 is the molecular volume, k is the Boltzmann constant and T the temperature. Thus, catalysts with small pores will give rise to precipitation at lower temperatures than catalysts with large pores. A catalytic hysteresis effect could be observed after reheating the deactivated sulphuric acid catalysts again in unconverted gas as shown in Fig. 5. The catalysts IK-768 and IK-739 are nearly based on the same chemical composition but with a different porous structure of the support. According to Fig. 5a the relative vanadium(IV) concentration increased slightly for both catalysts by 138 C. Oehlers et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 147 (1996) 127-144 lowering the temperature, whereas much more vanadium(IV) species were formed below the breakpoint temperature (region B-C). The precipitation of crystalline vanadium(IV) compounds increased further during 12 h at 345 (region C-D). By reheating the catalyst samples the vanadium(IV) amount decreased, indicating a reversible process in the melt. Furthermore, it can be noticed that the relative vanadium(IV) concentration drops below the curve obtained during the cooling process for the two catalysts. Most likely the precipitation of vanadium species both in the oxidation states + 3 (EPR-silent) and +4 at 345 can be assumed. Thus, upon reheating, first vanadium(IV) compounds decompose and form the catalytic active vanadium(V) complexes in the melt, but the catalytic activity was only fully regained at approximately 480 as shown in Fig. 5b where the vanadium(III) compounds also are reoxidized to vanadium(V) [12]. The influence of the porous structure on the hysteresis behavior seems to be important and more pronounced for the experiment where a sample of the IK-739 catalyst was pelletized under pressure (p = 0.3 GPa). A different deactivation compound and a lower turnover frequency was found for the pressed sample (Fig. 5b), most likely due to a change of the porous structure inducing mass transport restriction of the gas phase components. Due to the EPR parameter of the spectrum of the pressed sample, the precipitated compound could be classified as a mixed valence vanadium(IV-V) compound, probably Cs6(VO)4(504)8 analogous to K6(VO)4(SO4)8, which recently has been isolated from model melts [25]. The calculated values giso = 1.974 and A Bpp = 67 Gauss show good accordance with the EPR data of the sodium and potassium mixed valence compounds [25,26]. This is surprising, because so far all mixed valence vanadium(IV-V) compounds containing Cs, Na, K have been synthesised in highly preconverted gas. Therefore the change of physical properties seems to influence strongly the chemical processes in the catalyst melt. The activity measurements based on vanadium(V) showed that under steady- state conditions and high SO2 partial pressures (i.e. low conversion) the catalytic reaction most likely takes place without a change in the oxidation state of vanadium even below the breakpoint temperature Tb, since no break can be observed. A straight line could not be obtained for the catalyst IK-768 in the high temperature region, probably due to its very high activity leading to full conversion of the gas. Thus, in contrast to an earlier publication [3], the so-called 'associative mechanism' seems to be dominant also at low temperature and at low conversion. The active species in the catalytic cycle are considered to be polynuclear complexes of vanadium in the oxidation state (V) coordinated to sulphate and/or pyrosulphate ligands [27,28]. The synthesis and characterization of the dimeric vanadium(V) compound Cs4(WO)20(SO4)4, which could be an initial component in the reaction mechanism, is described in [29]. The redox reaction of vanadium is a side reaction in equilibrium with the catalytic cycle [7,28]. At lower temperatures the equilibrium reaction, leading to deactivation, C. Oehlers et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 147 (1996) 127-144 139 dominates the whole catalytic process, since the active species are reduced to inactive vanadium compounds. The formation of vanadium(IV) deactivation compounds, below the break- point temperature Tb, resulted in EPR spectra with different g-values and line widths (Table 3). The chemical composition of the catalyst as well as the partial pressures of SO2 and SO3 have a strong influence on the type of deactivation compound. High SO2 conversion favours the formation of vanadylsulphate-like compounds containing SO2 and/or SO3 in their structure but without alkali metal ions [30]. The formation of vanadium(III) species at low SO2 conversion is more likely than under high, due to a shift of the equilibrium (Eq. 1) to lower oxidation states. The role of vanadium(III) deactivation compounds in the catalysts for sulphuric acid production as shown here by the hysteresis behavior and during flue gas cleaning [31] has so far been underestimated. This is supported by earlier investigations of model melts [12]. 4.2. Co, stallization modeling Crystallization processes in the melt of sulphuric acid catalysts can be described on the basis of a statistical lattice type model by changing the parameters of temperature, SO2 conversion and chemical composition. The used model includes local interactions between the cells like in the Ising models and is independent of the uniform distribution of the reagents and the catalytically active complexes across the reaction system in contrary to the traditional models. The catalyst melt was modeled by a cubic lattice consisting of N 3 cells, each containing one of the binuclear complexes (V5+)2 or (V4+)2. There are only four mutual orientations of two neighbouring dimers: (1) consecutive (-- --), (2) parallel (LI), (3) perpendicular (1) and (4) crossed (+). The model is simplified by the approximation that the interaction energies for the perpendicu- lar and crossed orientations are zero since interaction between dimers are supposed to occur for either parallel or consecutive complex configurations. This leads to six different interaction energies between the neighbouring pairs of V4+V4+, V4+V5+ and Vs+VS+-dimers. The model lattice configuration (~) is defined by the orientations and types of the dimer. If these sets of dimer states are known, the energy of the given configuration E(~) can be calculated as the sum of the interaction energies for all the pairs of neighbouring dimers divided by a factor of two to avoid double counting. At a certain temperature the ratio c = [V4+]/[V5+] is constant for each ensemble of possible lattice configurations (~), and it can be calculated from the temperature, the composition of the gas mixture and the chemical composition of the catalyst according to the equation obtained from earlier kinetic investigations [7]. The mentioned method is a standard routine which enables the simulation of a thermodynamic equilibrium in Gibbs ensembles. The algorithm starts from the arbitrary initial configuration ~o. The current configuration ~s is transformed into the next ~+1 configuration by the randomized procedure of the so-called Monte Carlo step. Conclusion Activity measurements of sulphuric acid catalysts revealed that at low SO2 conversion degrees the so-called 'associative mechanism' dominates the cat- alytic reaction, i.e. the vanadium oxidation state of the active polynuclear vanadium(V) complexes remains unchanged in the catalytic cycle. Different crystalline vanadium compounds are formed during the deactivation process at low and high SO2 conversion. The increasing p(SO3)/p(SO2) ratio leads to the formation of vanadium(IV) compounds with less SO2- per VO2unit, proba- bly due to a shift of the solvent equilibrium SO3 + SO2- ~ $2O2- to the right. The deactivation of SO2 oxidation catalysts is a reversible process. However, by reheating the deactivated catalysts the relative vanadium(IV) concentration shows hysteresis and drops below the curve obtained during the cooling process, indicating that vanadium species both in the oxidation states (III) and (IV) are formed. Physical parameters like the pore size influences the deactivation process as well as the catalytic activity. The reactions which take place in the homogeneous phase of the catalyst pores are complex and therefore modeling of these processes is quite difficult. Nevertheless a new statistical lattice type model can describe the position of the breakpoint temperature Tb very accu- rately at different SO2 conversion degrees and for catalysts with different chemical compositions.
